awd_titl_txt: Food Security and Lactic Bacteria Use in Alaska and the Bering Strait Region
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines traditional methods of processing and preserving Arctic subsistence food products through the means of aging and fermentation.  In collaboration with resident experts of the Bering Strait region, the project team will conduct ethnographic fieldwork and develop a systemic framework for understanding the role of fermentation in Arctic societies and the multiple factors that affect the methods and processes of fermentation. Among those factors are interactions of the built environment and physical geography, household dynamics, and generational perspectives on diet and health. 
 
The intellectual merit of the project involves utilizing the novel approach of exploring fermentation as a domain of local ecological knowledge. The project will advance research on the relationships between Arctic food preparation practices, public health, housing, and social/environmental conditions. This study will contribute to the momentum of the emergent interest in infrastructure within Arctic scholarship and across several fields of engineering and science. Broader impacts include student training and public outreach, and insights that may inform the development of architectural designs, construction materials, and community planning that function in greater cohesion with the cultural needs of the Arctic societies.

por.por_cntn:
This is a community-initiated project dedicated to a broadly reaching study of food and culture in the region of the Bering Strait. Bringing together a diverse set of expertise in anthropology, marine biology, humanities, Indigenous scholarship, and coastal marine ecosystem studies, our research team, based at the University of Alaska Fairbanks, has developed this project at the request of the Chukchi, Yupik, and Inupiaq culture bearers, community-based educators, leaders, and active youth, interested in a co-production and exchange of knowledge that speaks to their region?s foodways, food security, and cuisines. The predominant research focus has been the methods of aging and fermentation used to prepare and preserve the products coming from the locally harvested plants, animals, fungi, and fish. We aimed to investigate the processes, technologies and infrastructure, social-cultural practices, human-environmental interactions, and adaptation to both social and environmental change as they connect to aging and fermentation ? a core component in the foodways of the maritime hunter and reindeer herder societies. From the early developmental phases and throughout the life of the project, the research questions, work plan, and activities aimed at dissemination, education, public engagement, and professional development were being conducted and continuously reevaluated with the participation and support of the community-based contributors.

Throughout the Arctic, people employ aging and fermentation to prepare and preserve their locally sourced foods, as well as to create materials used to make clothing, watercraft, drums, a rich variety of visual art, and many other household objects. Recognized as biocultural processes, which through a timed exposure to a right set of conditions in an environment identified or created to serve the preparer?s aim, aging and fermentation are appreciated for their capacity to transform the sensory and physical properties of a substance to become food and material culture items, valued for the sensory, aesthetic, nutritional, and utilitarian qualities that fulfill one?s personal, cultural, and community needs. Thanks to this capacity, aging and fermentation link people and place through the interaction of local climate, terrain, built environment, cultural expression, and social-economic values that inform the cultural measures of food security, community vitality, and adoptive strength. Such knowledge and skill constitute a dynamic and experimental domain of local expertise that is being perpetually adapted to the changing social and environmental conditions.

With anthropology as its principal discipline and with humanities, art, and social and natural sciences expertise represented among its collaborators and leadership, the project helped produce close to ninety products that include peer reviewed articles and book chapters, contributions to popular periodicals, museum and gallery exhibitions, presentations at professional conferences, and multimedia materials for outreach and public engagement. Widely inclusive in the academic and public audiences that it has reached, and continues to reach, this output constitutes an original body of knowledge of the culinary principles, material culture, social and aesthetic values, generational continuities and shifts, regional variability, and broader social and human-environmental interactions entangled within the food systems and practices of cuisine in the Bering Strait. 

The project provided direct mentoring, research, and professional development support to students in BA, MA, and PhD programs, pursuing degrees in Anthropology, Art, Indigenous Studies, Rural Development, One Health, Resilience and Adaptation at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. Most of these students are members of underrepresented groups and groups that have been disproportionally affected by the Covid-19 Pandemic. The opportunities that this project provided were instrumental in the success of these students, making it possible for them to advance and thrive in their degree programs and find fulfilling professional employment in their field. The concepts, methodologies, ethnographic insights, visual materials, and outreach developed over the life of the project has been integrated broadly integrated across the University of Alaska Fairbanks anthropology curriculum, informing lecture materials and seminar discussions in a number of introductory courses and these upper level and graduate courses: Food and Culture, Inuit Art, Indigenous Art and Culture, Economic Anthropology, Ethnomycology, Northern Indigenous People and Contemporary Issues. The curricular materials and educational experiences that this project helped create has reached well over a thousand students, and we expect this number to continue to grow. We are especially happy to report that our pedagogical framework we employ, which was informed in great part by this project?s research and outreach activities, aligns with the recommendations of the National Academies recommendation for the integration of the humanities and arts with sciences, engineering, and medicine in higher Education.

The experiences and products of this project help inform food security and food safety policies, home design, and food and utilities infrastructure in the rural Arctic. Most importantly, they helped facilitate coproduction, transgenerational transfer, and exchange of knowledge between cohorts and communities, promoting cultural vitality, growth of the human capital, and capacity to adapt to the ongoing social and environmental change.
